CFDocument.creator: Georgia Department of Education
CFDocument.title: Georgia’s K-12 Standards for English Language Arts (SY2025-2026)
CFDocument.description:
**Georgia’s K-12 Standards for English Language Arts will be fully implemented in the 2025-2026 school year. The Georgia Standards of Excellence (GSE) for English Language Arts will remain active in 2023-2024 and 2024-2025 and can be accessed here (and then include that link).**
The Georgia Standard
subject: English

CFItems.fullStatement: **Grammar, Usage, & Mechanics**
**Usage:** Use nouns and verbs to share complete thoughts when speaking.
**Usage:** Form and use singular and plural nouns when speaking.
**Usage:** Use interrogatives to ask questions when speaking.
**Mechanics:** Capitalize the first word of a sentence and the pronoun *I*.
**Grammar:** Form regular plural nouns by adding -s or -es.
**Grammar:** Form and use verbs by adding -ing, -ed, or -s.
**Grammar:** Use action verbs.
**Grammar:** Use adjectives and adverbs.
**Grammar:** Use common and proper nouns.
**Grammar:** Form and use the simple verb tenses.
**Usage:** Use determiners (articles, possessive determiners, demonstrative adjectives).
**Mechanics:** Capitalize proper nouns.
**Mechanics:** Use periods, exclamation marks, and question marks at the end of sentences.
**Grammar:** Form plural nouns by changing -y to -ies.
**Grammar:** Use personal pronouns (subject, object, and possessive).
**Grammar:** Use frequently occurring prepositions.
**Mechanics:** Use commas to separate items in a series and to format dates, addresses, salutations, and closings.
**Mechanics:** Use apostrophes to form contractions and singular possessive nouns.
**Grammar:** Form and use irregular plural nouns.
**Grammar:** Form and use the past tense of irregular verbs.
**Grammar:** Use coordinating conjunctions to join words, phrases, or clauses.
**Grammar:** Form and use verbs by adding -d or -es.
**Grammar:** Use collective and abstract nouns.
**Grammar:** Use reflexive pronouns.
**Mechanics:** Use commas with coordinating conjunctions to join independent clauses.
**Mechanics:** Use hyphens to divide words at line breaks.
**Grammar:** Form and use prepositional phrases.
**Grammar:** Form and use comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs.
**Usage:** Ensure pronoun-antecedent agreement.
**Mechanics:** Recognize and use conventional capitalization, quotation marks, and commas to indicate exact words and dialogue.
**Grammar:** Use relative pronouns and relative adverbs.
**Grammar:** Use interjections.
**Grammar:** Use helping and linking verbs.
**Usage:** Correctly use frequently confused words (e.g., to/too/two; there/their/they’re; advice/advise).
**Mechanics:** Recognize and use conventional capitalization in abbreviations, proper adjectives, and formal titles.
**Mechanics:** Use commas to indicate direct address and to set off the words *yes* and *no*.
**Mechanics:** Use apostrophes to form plural possessives nouns.
**Grammar:** Use indefinite pronouns, ensuring correct agreement.
**Grammar:** Use subordinating conjunctions to join clauses.
**Mechanics:** Use commas after introductory phrases or clauses.
**Mechanics:** Use conventional capitalization and underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.
**Grammar:** Use intensive pronouns.
**Grammar:** Form and use the progressive, perfect, and perfect progressive verb aspects.
**Grammar:** Form and use participles.
**Usage:** Recognize and correct vague pronoun references.
**Grammar:** Use correlative conjunctions to join words, phrases, or clauses.
**Mechanics:** Use conventional capitalization, quotation marks, commas, end punctuation, and attributions to indicate exact words and lines of dialogue.
**Mechanics:** Use semicolons to separate items in a series or list when at least one of the items already contains commas.
**Mechanics:** Use commas, parentheses, and dashes to set off nonessential words, phrases, or clauses.
**Mechanics:** Use ellipses appropriately.
**Mechanics:** Use hyphens with appropriate affixes and compound words.
**Mechanics:** Use semicolons, with or without a conjunctive adverb, to form compound and compound-complex sentences.
**Grammar, Mechanics** Use parts of speech and their associated phrases or clauses to perform indicated sentence functions (e.g., subject, direct object, predicate nominative, modifier).
**Mechanics:** Use conventional capitalization, quotation marks, commas, end punctuation, and parentheses (citations) when incorporating textual evidence.
**Grammar:** Use demonstrative pronouns.
**Mechanics:** Use colons to introduce lists, examples, and explanations.
**Usage:** Form and use verbals and verbal phrases (participles/participials, gerunds, and infinitives) based on function.
**Usage:** Use tenses and aspects to indicate the mood of a verb.
**Mechanics:** Use colons to introduce quotations.
**Mechanics:** Use dashes appropriately.
**Grammar, Usage, Mechanics:** Use an appropriate style guide to address complex issues of grammar, usage, or mechanics.
Elementary English Language Arts K-5
Language Arts/Grade Kindergarten
**DOMAIN: Foundations (F)** Students build a foundation for achieving dynamic literacy practices to aid reading comprehension.

**DOMAIN: Language (L)** Students learn and apply the structures and conventions of standard English. Students observe and analyze how grammar works in reading and writing. Students build vocabularies and determine word meanings as they relate to reading and writing.
**I. BIG IDEA: Grammar Conventions** Students observe, analyze, and use the structures and conventions of Standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics as they interpret and construct texts.

**Grammar, Usage, & Mechanics** Learn and apply conventions of Standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics to aid the comprehension of texts and to communicate clearly in written and spoken language.
**Usage:** Use nouns and verbs to share complete thoughts when speaking. (Introduce, Master)
**Usage:** Form and use singular and plural nouns when speaking. (Introduce, Master)
**Usage:** Use interrogatives to ask questions when speaking. (Introduce, Master)
**Mechanics:** Capitalize the first word of a sentence and the pronoun *I*. (Introduce, Master)
**Grammar:** Form regular plural nouns by adding -s or -es. (Introduce)
**Grammar:** Form and use verbs by adding -ing, -ed, or -s. (Introduce)
**Grammar:** Use action verbs. (Introduce)
**Grammar:** Use adjectives and adverbs. (Introduce)
**Grammar:** Use common and proper nouns. (Introduce)
**Grammar:** Form and use the simple verb tenses. (Introduce)
**Usage:** Use determiners (articles, possessive determiners, demonstrative adjectives). (Introduce)
**Mechanics:** Capitalize proper nouns. (Introduce)
**Mechanics:** Use periods, exclamation marks, and question marks at the end of sentences. (Introduce)
**DOMAIN: Texts (T)** Students grow in their learning as they purposefully engage with texts.

Grade 12 standards

**DOMAIN: Language (L)** Students learn and apply the structures and conventions of standard English. Students observe and analyze how grammar works in reading and writing. Students build vocabularies and determine word meanings as they relate to reading and writing.
**DOMAIN: Texts (T)** Students grow in their learning as they purposefully engage with texts.
**Syntax** Recognize and compose coherent sentences that express complete thoughts.
Recognize that conventional sentences always include a subject and a predicate. (I)
With adult support, use simple sentences to express complete thoughts in written texts. (C)
With adult support, use singular and plural subjects with matching verbs. (C)

**II. BIG IDEA: Vocabulary** Students engage in a wide range of written and spoken activities during which they expand and deepen their vocabularies, build word analysis skillsets (morphology), and determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.
**General, Academic, & Specialized Vocabulary** Acquire and use general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases in a variety of settings.
Acquire and apply general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases through grade-level texts and content. (I)
Use grade-level general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases to communicate in a variety of settings. (C)
**Meaning & Purpose** Make connections between words and phrases and use reference materials to determine or clarify word meanings in a variety of settings and for a variety of purposes.
With adult support, determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases. (I)
Identify and sort common words into basic categories based on similarities and differences. (I)
Use knowledge of word relationships and learned vocabulary words and phrases when making word choices in speaking and writing. (C)
**Syntax** Recognize and compose coherent sentences that express complete thoughts.
Distinguish between complete and incomplete simple sentences, and identify sentence type (i.e., declarative, imperative, interrogative, and exclamatory). (I)
Use a variety of simple sentences (including a variety of sentence types) to develop clarity in written texts. (C)
Use singular and plural subjects with matching verbs. (C)
With adult support, use adjectives or adverbs to add details or clarify meaning. (C)

**II. BIG IDEA: Vocabulary** Students engage in a wide range of written and spoken activities during which they expand and deepen their vocabularies, build word analysis skillsets (morphology), and determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.
**General, Academic, & Specialized Vocabulary** Acquire and use general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases in a variety of settings.
Acquire and apply general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases through grade-level texts and content. (I)
Use grade-level general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases to communicate in a variety of settings. (C)
**Word Analysis** Acquire and apply word analysis skills to deconstruct and construct words to make meaning.
Identify frequently occurring root words (e.g., look) and inflectional endings used to form and comprehend new words (e.g., looks, looked, looking). (I)
Construct words using frequently occurring roots words and inflectional endings. (C)
**Meaning & Purpose** Make connections between words and phrases and use reference materials to determine or clarify word meanings in a variety of settings and for a variety of purposes.
Use context within and beyond a sentence to determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases. (I)
Identify the relationship between words and their synonyms and antonyms. (I)
Distinguish shades of meaning among verbs that describe the same general action (e.g., walk, march, strut, prance). (I)
With teacher support, use a picture dictionary or digital resource to clarify the meaning of unknown words and phrases. (I)
Use knowledge of word relationships and learned vocabulary words and phrases when making word choices in speaking and writing. (C)
**Syntax** Recognize and compose coherent sentences that express complete thoughts.
Distinguish between simple and compound sentences, and identify the sentence type (i.e., declarative, imperative, interrogative, and exclamatory). (I)
Use a variety of simple and compound sentences (including a variety of sentence types) to develop clarity and coherence in written texts. (C)
Use correct subject and verb agreement in sentence constructions. (C)
Develop ideas or information in texts by using adjectives or adverbs to add details or clarify meaning. (C)

**II. BIG IDEA: Vocabulary** Students engage in a wide range of written and spoken activities during which they expand and deepen their vocabularies, build word analysis skillsets (morphology), and determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.
**General, Academic, & Specialized Vocabulary** Acquire and use general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases in a variety of settings.
Acquire and apply general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases through grade-level texts and content. (I)
Use grade-level general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases to communicate in a variety of settings. (C)
**Word Analysis** Acquire and apply word analysis skills to deconstruct and construct words to make meaning.
Identify and use frequently occurring root words and affixes (e.g., prefixes, suffixes) to deconstruct words to determine or clarify meaning. (I)
Construct words using frequently occurring root words and affixes. (C)
**Meaning & Purpose** Make connections between words and phrases and use reference materials to determine or clarify word meanings in a variety of settings and for a variety of purposes.
Use context within and beyond a sentence to determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases. (I)
Determine the relationship between words and their synonyms and antonyms. (I)
Distinguish shades of meaning among verbs that differ in manner (e.g., look, peek, glance, stare, glare, scowl) and adjectives that differ in intensity (e.g., large, gigantic). (I)
Use glossaries and beginning dictionaries, both print and digital, to determine or clarify the meaning of words and phrases. (I)
Use knowledge of word relationships and learned vocabulary words and phrases when making word choices in speaking and writing. (C)

**I. BIG IDEA: Phonological Awareness** Students develop the ability to identify and produce the sound structures of spoken language and how they can be divided into smaller components and manipulated.
**Rhyme** Identify and produce rhyme in spoken language and oral texts.
Identify and pair words that rhyme in spoken language, distinguishing them from those that do not.
Orally produce words that rhyme.
**Words & Sentences** Recognize the basic relationships that exist between words and sentences.
Know words are put together to make sentences, and sentences communicate complete thoughts.
Segment phrases and sentences into words.
Know that sounds are put together to make words and that words have distinct meanings. ​
**Compound Words** Identify and manipulate separate words in compound words.
Blend and segment separate words in spoken compound words.
Add, delete, and substitute single words in spoken compound words.
**Syllables** Identify and manipulate syllables in spoken words.
Know that syllables are word parts with one vowel sound.
Count and pronounce syllables in single and multisyllabic spoken words.
Blend and segment syllables in spoken words.
Delete syllables in spoken words.
**Onsets & Rimes** Blend and segment onsets and rimes in spoken words.
Blend onsets and rimes of spoken one-syllable words.
Segment onsets and rimes of spoken one-syllable words.
**Phonemic Awareness** Identify and manipulate the individual sounds in spoken words.
Isolate and pronounce initial, final, and then medial sounds in spoken words with three phonemes.
Identify short and long vowel sounds in spoken one-syllable words.
Blend, count, and segment up to three phonemes in spoken one-syllable words.
Add, delete, and substitute phonemes in spoken one-syllable words with up to three phonemes.
**II. BIG IDEA: Concepts of Print** Students develop the awareness that written language carries meaning and that certain features of print ensure that texts are understood.
**Conceptualizing Text** Understand that texts communicate messages.
Recognize that texts and images represent objects and ideas, have meaning, and convey messages.
Recognize and interpret print messages in the environment, such as labels and signs.
Distinguish between letters, words, digits, and graphics.
**Book Orientation & Directionality of Print Texts** Understand the conventional layout of books and how to maneuver them.
Hold books upright and begin reading at the front.
Follow text from top to bottom, left to right, and turn pages from right to left.
Identify the front and back covers of books and their basic elements: titles, author names, illustrator names, and graphics.
**Mechanics of Print Texts** Build a knowledge base of print conventions.
Recognize that written words are made up of individual letters.
Recognize that words are separated by spaces.
Understand that sentences begin with capital letters and end with punctuation to indicate the end of a sentence.
**Alphabet Knowledge** Demonstrate knowledge of the alphabet.
Recite the letters of the alphabet in order.
Name and identify each uppercase and lowercase letter in random order.
**III. BIG IDEA: Phonics** Students learn the relationships between the sounds of spoken language and the letters of written language as they decode and encode words in context and in isolation.
**Phoneme-Grapheme Correspondences** Identify and produce phoneme-grapheme correspondences.
Identify and produce basic one-to-one phoneme-grapheme correspondences for the most frequently used sound for each consonant.
Identify and produce both long and short vowel sounds for A, E, I, O, U.
**Decoding with Phonics** Use grade-level phonics skills to decode words in context and in isolation.
Blend letter sounds to decode simple one-syllable words, including regularly spelled high-frequency words (VC, CV, CVC).
Identify and decode parts of irregularly spelled high-frequency words.
Identify and distinguish between words that are spelled similarly by identifying the sounds of the letters that differ.
**Encoding with Phonics** Use grade-level phonics skills to encode words in context and in isolation.
Use knowledge of letter/sound correspondences to connect letters (graphemes) to sounds (phonemes) to encode simple one-syllable words, including high-frequency words (VC, CV, CVC). ​
Identify and encode irregularly spelled high- frequency words.
**IV. BIG IDEA: Fluency** Students read text aloud or silently with speed, accuracy, and expression.
**Oral & Silent Reading Fluency** Demonstrate oral and silent reading fluency while reading grade-level texts for understanding, self-correcting as necessary to ensure accuracy and aid comprehension.

Develop sight word vocabulary using decoding skills by reading regularly and irregularly spelled high-frequency words in isolation and context with increasing automaticity, including first and last names of students and others.
Read familiar texts chorally with appropriate volume and rate.
Read grade-level texts with purpose and understanding.
**V. BIG IDEA: Handwriting** Students develop print handwriting skills.
**Motor Skills & Letter/Word Formation** Use fine motor skills to form legible letters and words in print.
Form all uppercase and lowercase letters.
Form words, including first and last names.
Use appropriate spacing between letters, words, and sentences.
**Transcription & Handwriting Fluency** Use working memory to transcribe oral language to written text and maintain meaning while writing letters, words, and sentences quickly and accurately.
Practice basic transcription skills.
Begin building handwriting fluency by forming accurate letters, including those in first and last names.

**I. BIG IDEA: Phonological Awareness** Students develop the ability to identify and produce the sound structures of spoken language and how they can be divided into smaller components and manipulated.
**Syllables** Identify and manipulate syllables in spoken words.
Reinforce as appropriate.
Reinforce as appropriate.
Reinforce as appropriate.
Add, delete, and substitute syllables in spoken words. ​
Blend onsets and rimes of spoken one-syllable words with blends, digraphs, and trigraphs in the initial and final positions. ​
Segment onsets and rimes of spoken one-syllable words with blends, digraphs, and trigraphs in the initial and final positions.
Isolate and pronounce initial, medial, and final sounds in spoken one- syllable words, including words with digraphs and blends.
Distinguish between short and long vowel sounds in spoken one-syllable words.
Blend and segment up to five phonemes, including consonant blends and digraphs, in spoken words.
Add, delete, and substitute phonemes in spoken one-syllable words with three or more phonemes.
**III. BIG IDEA: Phonics** Students learn the relationships between the sounds of spoken language and the letters of written language as they decode and encode words in context and in isolation.
**Phoneme-Grapheme Correspondences** Identify and produce phoneme-grapheme correspondences.
Identify and produce phoneme-grapheme correspondences for frequently used consonant blends and digraphs. ​
Identify and produce both long and short vowel sounds for A, E, I, O, U, including final -e and vowel digraphs.
**Decoding with Phonics** Use grade-level phonics skills to decode words in context and in isolation.
Decode regularly spelled one-syllable words with a variety of spelling patterns (VC, CV, CVC, CVCe, VCC, CCVC, CVCC, CCVCC), including high-frequency words.
Identify and decode parts of irregularly spelled words, including high-frequency words.
Decode one-syllable nonsense words with a variety of spelling patterns (VC, CVC, CVCe, VCC, CCVC, CVCC, CCVCC). ​
Decode two-syllable words with basic patterns by applying knowledge of basic syllable types. ​
**Encoding with Phonics** Use grade-level phonics skills to encode words in context and in isolation.
Encode regularly spelled one-syllable words with a variety of spelling patterns (VC, CVC, CVCe, VCC, CCVC, CVCC, CCVCC), including high-frequency words.
Identify and encode irregularly spelled words, including high-frequency words.
Encode one-syllable nonsense words with a variety of spelling patterns (VC, CVC, CVCe, VCC, CCVC, CVCC, CCVCC).
Encode two-syllable words with basic patterns by applying knowledge of basic syllable types.
**IV. BIG IDEA: Fluency** Students read text aloud or silently with speed, accuracy, and expression.
**Oral & Silent Reading Fluency** Demonstrate oral and silent reading fluency while reading grade-level texts for understanding, self-correcting as necessary to ensure accuracy and aid comprehension.

Increase sight word vocabulary using decoding skills by reading grade- appropriate regularly and irregularly spelled words, including high-frequency words, in isolation and context with increasing automaticity.
Read a wide range of grade-level texts aloud with increasing accuracy.
Read a wide range of grade-level texts aloud with appropriate prosody (phrasing, expression, juncture/pause, and intonation) to demonstrate understanding.
Self-correct while reading text (silently or aloud) to improve comprehension and fluency, rereading as necessary.
**V. BIG IDEA: Handwriting** Students develop print handwriting skills.
**Motor Skills & Letter/Word Formation** Use fine motor skills to form legible letters and words in print.
Form all uppercase and lowercase letters and words with accuracy and consistency.
Form words with accuracy and consistency.
Use appropriate spacing between letters, words, and sentences across lines on a page.
**Transcription & Handwriting Fluency** Use working memory to transcribe oral language to written text and maintain meaning while writing letters, words, and sentences quickly and accurately.
Perform basic transcription skills.
Build handwriting fluency by forming accurate letters and words with increasing speed.
**III. BIG IDEA: Phonics** Students learn the relationships between the sounds of spoken language and the letters of written language as they decode and encode words in context and in isolation.

Identify and produce both long and short vowel sounds for A, E, I, O, U, including final -e, vowel digraphs, r-controlled vowels, and diphthongs. ​
**Decoding with Phonics** Use grade-level phonics skills to decode words in context and in isolation.
Decode regularly spelled two-syllable words with a variety of spelling patterns (VVCC, VVCe, VCCC, VVCCC) by applying knowledge of basic phonics skills, including high-frequency words.
Identify and decode parts of irregularly spelled words, including high-frequency words.
Decode two-syllable nonsense words by applying rules of basic phonics skills (VVCC, VVCe, VCCC, VVCCC).
Decode two-syllable words by applying knowledge of all major syllable types.
**Encoding with Phonics** Use grade-level phonics skills to encode words in context and in isolation.
Encode regularly spelled two-syllable words with a variety of spelling patterns (VVCC, VVCe, VCCC, VVCCC) by applying knowledge of basic phonics skills, including high- frequency words.
Identify and encode irregularly spelled words, including high-frequency words.
Encode two-syllable nonsense words with a variety of spelling patterns (VVCC, VVCe, VCCC, VVCCC).
Encode two-syllable words by applying knowledge of all major syllable types.

**Oral & Silent Reading Fluency** Demonstrate oral and silent reading fluency while reading grade-level texts for understanding, self-correcting as necessary to ensure accuracy and aid comprehension.

Increase sight word vocabulary using decoding skills by reading grade appropriate regularly and irregularly spelled words, including high-frequency words, in isolation and context with increasing automaticity.
Read a wide range of grade-level texts aloud with increasing automaticity.
Read a wide range of grade-level texts aloud with appropriate prosody (phrasing, expression, juncture/pause, and intonation) to demonstrate understanding.
Self-correct while reading text (silently or aloud) to improve comprehension and fluency, rereading as necessary. ​
**V. BIG IDEA: Handwriting** Students develop print handwriting skills.
**Motor Skills & Letter/Word Formation** Use fine motor skills to form legible letters and words in print.
Form all uppercase and lowercase letters and words with accuracy, consistency, and efficiency. ​
Form words and sentences efficiently.
Use appropriate spacing throughout the body of a text.
**Transcription & Handwriting Fluency** Use working memory to transcribe oral language to written text and maintain meaning while writing letters, words, and sentences quickly and accurately.
Efficiently and accurately transcribe text.
Track and maintain speed and efficiency while forming words and sentences.
**I. BIG IDEA: Context** Students explore the relationships and roles of authors, purposes, and audiences of texts.
**Purpose & Audience** Explain how authors of texts use language for a specific purpose and a target audience.
Identify the general purpose (e.g., to tell stories, to provide information, to share opinions) and target audience in a variety of texts. (I)
With adult support, identify different modes of communication: print, digital, auditory, and visual. (I)
With adult support, create texts in various modes (e.g., print, digital, auditory, and/or visual). (C)
**Authors & Speakers** Investigate the relationships between authors and speakers in texts.
Identify the authors and illustrators of picture books and explain their roles. (I)
**II. BIG IDEA: Structures & Style** Students build and apply knowledge about language and organizational structures and elements used to convey and arrange ideas and information in texts.
**Organization** Identify and use organizational structures to craft meaning.
Identify and use text features, including titles, headings, photos, and illustrations, to determine if a text is fiction or nonfiction. (I)
With adult support, use text features, including titles, illustrations, and/or labels to add clarity/coherence to texts. (C)
With adult support, retell events and actions in sequence. (C)
**Craft** Identify and use descriptive and engaging language.
Identify interesting and/or descriptive words that express feelings or appeal to the senses in texts. (I)
With adult support, use interesting and/or descriptive words to craft engaging texts. (C)
**III. BIG IDEA: Techniques** Students identify and use narrative, expository, opinion, and poetic techniques as they interpret and construct a variety of texts.
**Narrative Techniques** Identify and use narrative techniques to shape understanding.
Identify techniques used to craft stories, including characters, setting, and major events. (I)
With adult support, demonstrate an understanding of the central message, lesson, or moral of the story based on the words and actions of the main characters. (I)
With adult support, compare and contrast characters and their experiences in stories across diverse cultures. (I)
Use a combination of drawing, labeling, writing, and dictating* to create a text with narrative techniques (e.g., characters, setting, events) told in the order in which they occurred. (C)
CFItems.notes: *Dictating should only be used when necessary to check for understanding.

CFItems.fullStatement: **Expository Techniques** Identify and use expository techniques to shape understanding.
Identify techniques used to craft expository texts, including main topic. (I)
With adult support, describe the connection between two individuals, events, ideas, or pieces of information in a text. (I)
Use a combination of drawing, labeling, writing, and dictating* to create a text with expository techniques that includes a topic and information about the topic. (C)
CFItems.notes: *Dictating should only be used when necessary to check for understanding.

CFItems.fullStatement: **Opinion Techniques** Identify and use opinion techniques to shape understanding.
Explain the difference between opinions and facts about a topic. (I)
Use a combination of drawing, labeling, writing, and dictating* to express an opinion about a topic. (C)
CFItems.notes: *Dictating should only be used when necessary to check for understanding.

CFItems.fullStatement: **Poetic Techniques** Identify and use poetic techniques to shape understanding.
Identify poetic techniques used to craft poetic texts, including rhyme. (I)
With adult support, use poetic techniques to create poems that may or may not rhyme. (C)
**IV. BIG IDEA: Research & Analysis** Students use, discuss, analyze, and curate texts as they engage in various conversations, activities, and projects about a range of grade-level texts and topics.

**Research & Inquiry** Build knowledge about the world by asking or generating questions about topics of interest, researching the answers, using multiple sources, and communicating relevant and accurate information about the topic.
With adult support, ask questions about topics of interest for research. (I)

With adult support, collaborate to conduct research on a shared topic of interest by gathering and organizing information from provided sources (including print, digital, and personal communication) using graphic organizers or other support aids. (I)
With adult support, share relevant and accurate information through a variety of different modes. (C)
**Curating Sources & Evidence** Reference parts of texts to address a specific topic or question and explore various sources of information to make connections across a broad range of topics.
With adult support, refer to parts of texts when supporting an idea, answer, or opinion. (I)
With adult support, explore various sources of information, including print, digital, and personal communication. (I)

Use text features (e.g., illustrations, page numbers, bold print, headings) to add clarity and meaning to texts. (C)
Use transition words or phrases, such as *once upon a time*, *next*, and *last* to sequence events and actions. (C)

**Narrative Techniques** Identify and use narrative techniques to shape understanding.
Identify techniques used to craft stories, including characters, setting, major events, and dialogue. (I)
Identify a simple plot with a problem and solution. (I)
Describe traits of the main characters and explain how their words and actions support the central message, lesson, or moral of the story. (I)
With adult support, compare and contrast characters and their experiences in stories across diverse cultures. (I)
Use knowledge of narrative techniques (e.g., characters, settings, events) to create texts that share real or imagined experiences and events with a sense of closure. (C)
**Expository Techniques** Identify and use expository techniques to shape understanding.
Identify techniques used to craft expository texts, including main topic and supporting details. (I)
Describe the connection between two individuals, events, ideas, or pieces of information in a text. (I)
Use knowledge of expository techniques to introduce a topic, supply facts about the topic, and provide a sense of closure. (C)
**Opinion Techniques** Identify and use opinion techniques to shape understanding.
Identify techniques used to craft opinion texts, including the author’s opinion and supporting reasons. (I)

Use knowledge of opinion techniques to create opinion pieces that introduce the topic, state an opinion about the topic, and provides two or more reasons to support the opinion with linking words *and* and *because*. (C)
**Poetic Techniques** Identify and use poetic techniques to shape understanding.
Identify and describe poetic techniques used to craft texts, including rhyme, alliteration, and repeated lines. (I)
Use poetic techniques to create poems using simple words and/or phrases that may or may not rhyme. (C)

Apply understandings of sentence structure to comprehend a wide variety of grade-level texts. (I)
Use a variety of simple, compound, and complex sentences to strengthen clarity and coherence, maintaining consistent verb tense throughout the entire text. (C)
Use correct subject and verb agreement to consistently achieve clarity in a variety of sentences. (C)
Elaborate on ideas and information, using adjectives and adverbs when incorporating details and descriptions to convey precise meaning and engage audiences. (C)

**II. BIG IDEA: Vocabulary** Students engage in a wide range of written and spoken activities during which they expand and deepen their vocabularies, build word analysis skillsets (morphology), and determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.
**General, Academic, & Specialized Vocabulary** Acquire and use general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases with precision in a variety of settings.
Acquire a range of general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases through grade-level texts and content. (I)
Use grade-level general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases to enhance communication in a variety of settings. (C)
**Word Analysis** Acquire and apply word analysis skills to determine the meanings of words and to communicate with precision in a variety of settings.
Deconstruct words using common roots, root words, and affixes to determine meaning. (I)
Identify affixes associated with specific parts of speech (e.g., *ly* is commonly used with adverbs) to aid comprehension. (I)
Construct words using common roots, root words, and affixes. (C)
**Meaning & Purpose** Make connections between words and phrases and use reference materials to determine or clarify word meanings in a variety of settings and for a variety of purposes.
Use context (e.g., images and graphs) within and beyond a sentence to determine or clarify the meaning of unknown words and multiple-meaning words and phrases. (I)
Identify homophones and homographs and use the relationship between synonyms and antonyms to clarify word meanings. (I)
Distinguish shades of meaning among closely related verbs (e.g., toss, throw, hurl) and closely related adjectives (e.g., thin, slender, skinny, scrawny). (I)
Use glossaries or beginning dictionaries, both print and digital, to check spelling and to determine or clarify the precise meaning of words and phrases. (I)
Use knowledge of word relationships and learned vocabulary words and phrases to make precise word choices when speaking and writing. (C)

**II. BIG IDEA: Vocabulary** Students engage in a wide range of written and spoken activities during which they expand and deepen their vocabularies, build word analysis skillsets (morphology), and determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.
**General, Academic, & Specialized Vocabulary** Acquire and use general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases with precision in a variety of settings.
Acquire a range of general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases through grade-level texts and content. (I)
Use grade-level general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases to enhance communication in a variety of settings. (C)
**Word Analysis** Acquire and apply word analysis skills to determine the meanings of words and to communicate with precision in a variety of settings.
Deconstruct words using knowledge of Greek and Latin roots, root words, and affixes to determine meaning. (I)
Explain how the part of speech and the meaning of a root or root word changes based on the use of different affixes (e.g., *beautiful* as an adjective vs. *beautifully* as an adverb). (I)
Construct words using knowledge of Greek and Latin roots, root words, and affixes. (C)
**Meaning & Purpose** Make connections between words and phrases and use reference materials to determine or clarify word meanings in a variety of settings and for a variety of purposes.
Use context (e.g., definitions, examples, or restatements in text) to determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple- meaning words and phrases. (I)
Demonstrate understanding of words by relating them to their synonyms, antonyms, homophones, and homographs. (I)
Distinguish shades of meaning among closely related adverbs (e.g., quickly, swiftly, rapidly). (I)
Use print and digital reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses) to check spelling and determine or clarify the precise meaning of words and phrases. (I)
Use knowledge of word relationships and learned vocabulary words and phrases to make precise word choices when speaking and writing. (C)

**II. BIG IDEA: Vocabulary (V)** Students engage in a wide range of written and spoken activities during which they expand and deepen their vocabularies, build word analysis skillsets (morphology), and determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.
**General, Academic, & Specialized Vocabulary** Acquire and use general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases with precision in a variety of settings.
Acquire a range of general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases through grade-level texts and content. (I)
Use grade-level general, academic, and specialized vocabulary words and phrases to enhance communication in a variety of settings. (C)
**Word Analysis** Acquire and apply word analysis skills to determine the meanings of words and to communicate with precision in a variety of settings.
Deconstruct words using knowledge of Greek and Latin roots, root words, and affixes to determine meaning. (I)
Explain the connection between roots, root words, affixes, and parts of speech to determine the meaning of words (e.g., *discuss* as a verb vs. *discussion* as a noun). (I)
Construct words using knowledge of Greek and Latin roots, root words, and affixes. (C)
**Meaning & Purpose** Make connections between words and phrases and use reference materials to determine or clarify word meanings in a variety of settings and for a variety of purposes.
Use context (e.g., cause/effect relationships and comparisons in text) to determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases. (I)
Identify analogies and use synonyms, antonyms, homophones, and homographs to clarify intended meaning. (I)
Distinguish shades of meaning among related words, including verbs, adjectives, and/or adverbs, to clarify intended meaning. (I)
Use print and digital reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses) to check spelling and determine or clarify the precise meaning of words and phrases. (I)
Use knowledge of word relationships and learned vocabulary words and phrases to make precise word choices when speaking and writing. (C)
**I. BIG IDEA: Context** Students describe the influences of purpose and audience on texts.
**Purpose & Audience** Use knowledge of purposes and audiences, as well as the language that develops those relationships, to make meaning of texts in multiple modes.
Determine the purpose (e.g., entertain, inform, persuade) and target audience of a text. (I)
Recognize different texts by mode and describe how the different modes of communication: print, digital, auditory, spoken, visual, and multimodal, contribute to the overall purpose and effect. (I)
Create multimodal texts, using features of pre-selected modes for a specific purpose and audience. (C)
**Authors & Speakers** Make connections between authors of texts, speakers in texts, varying perspectives, and the circumstances in which texts are produced.
Describe different perspectives of the narrator or speakers and distinguish them from their own. (I)
This progression begins in 6th grade.
With adult support, identify the context in which a text is written (e.g., time period, individual, situational). (I)
**II. BIG IDEA: Structures & Style** Students build and apply knowledge about language and organizational structures and elements used to convey and arrange ideas and information in texts.
**Organization** Demonstrate and apply understanding of organizational structures and elements to create coherent and engaging texts.

Describe how texts are arranged to represent information and ideas using text features (e.g., map, captions) and organizational structures (e.g., cause/effect), referring to parts of texts using terms such as chapter or section. (I)
Design texts using a variety of text structures and features, according to purpose and audience. (C)
Use conjunctions and transition words or phrases, such as *although* and *since,* to add cohesion and link ideas and information. (C)
Craft related sentences into clear and cohesive paragraphs. (C)
**Craft** Use language to interpret meaning and craft engaging texts.
Identify and describe the use of figurative language, such as similes, metaphors, and idioms in a wide variety of texts. (I)
Use figurative language, such as similes, metaphors, and idioms, to show relationships between ideas and information. (C)
**III. BIG IDEA: Techniques** Students explain, analyze, and use various techniques to comprehend and shape meaning.
**Narrative Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use narrative techniques to shape understandings.
Explain how narrative techniques are used to present ideas, design texts, and convey information about characters, setting, and plot. (I)
Explain how characters, setting, problem, and solution function in the plot. (I)
Describe characters’ traits, motivations, actions, thoughts, and feelings and explain their connection to the central message, lesson, or moral of the story. (I)
Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, central messages, or events within texts across diverse cultures. (I)

Apply narrative techniques (e.g., character, setting, problem, resolution, dialogue) to develop a real or imagined experience using descriptive details, clear event sequences, and a sense of closure. (C)
**Expository Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use expository techniques to shape understandings.
Describe the techniques used to present and design expository texts, including facts and key details used to support the main idea. (I)
Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text. (I)
Integrate and explain information from two texts on the same topic in relationship to important points and key details. (I)
**Opinion Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use opinion techniques to shape understandings.
Describe and discuss the techniques used to present and design opinion texts, including author’s opinion statement, supporting reasons, and evidence. (I)

Apply opinion techniques to create opinion pieces that introduce the topic, state an opinion about the topic, supply reasons to support the opinion with linking words (e.g., because, therefore, since, for example) to connect the opinion and reasons, and provide a concluding statement or section. (C)
**Poetic Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use poetic techniques to shape understandings.
Discuss and explain techniques used to present and design poetry, including rhyme scheme. (I)
Apply poetic techniques to produce poetry and engage audiences that use rhyme in at least two stanzas to achieve an intended effect. (C)
**IV. BIG IDEA: Research & Analysis** Students use, discuss, analyze, and curate texts as they engage in various conversations, activities, and projects about a range of grade-level texts and topics.

**Research & Inquiry** Conduct research to ask and answer questions that clarify, deepen, and extend understanding of a topic of interest using credible sources and communicating relevant and accurate information.
Generate questions about a self-selected topic of interest to be researched, formulating additional questions to clarify or deepen understanding. (I)
Conduct research by locating, gathering, selecting, and organizing information from multiple credible sources, including print, digital, and personal communication, about a self-selected topic. (I)
Summarize researched, relevant, and accurate information from at least two credible sources about a self-selected topic. (C)
**Curating Sources & Evidence** Integrate evidence from print and digital sources, assessing credibility and relevance and avoiding plagiarism.
Refer to specific passages from a text to support an idea, answer, or opinion. (I)
Determine what makes a source text credible and relevant and identify examples. (I)
**I. BIG IDEA: Context** Students describe the influences of purpose and audience on texts.
**Purpose & Audience** Use knowledge of purposes and audiences, as well as the language that develops those relationships, to make meaning of texts in multiple modes.
Determine audience and identify the development of the purpose across a text. (I)
Classify various texts by mode and describe how the mode is impacted by audiences and contributes to the overall purpose and effect. (I)
Create multimodal texts, using features of pre-selected modes for a specific purpose and audience. (C)
**Authors & Speakers** Make connections between authors of texts, speakers in texts, varying perspectives, and the circumstances in which texts are produced.
Compare and contrast the perspectives of different narrators or speakers in a text. (I)
This progression begins in 6th grade.
Identify the context in which a text is written (e.g., time period, individual, situational). (I)
**II. BIG IDEA: Structures & Style** Students build and apply knowledge about language and organizational structures and elements used to convey and arrange ideas and information in texts.
**Organization** Demonstrate and apply understanding of organizational structures and elements to create coherent and engaging texts.

Compare and contrast the text features (e.g. icons, hyperlinks) and structures (e.g. chronological order, rhyme pattern) of texts written in different genres/for certain purposes, on the same topic. (I)
Design texts using a variety of text structures and features, according to purpose and audience. (C)
Use conjunctions and transition words or phrases, such as *similarly* and *in contrast,* to show relationships between ideas and information. (C)
Craft related sentences into cohesive paragraphs that follow a chosen structure using transitions. (C)
**Craft** Use language to interpret meaning and craft engaging texts.
Identify and explain how figurative language, such as hyperboles and personification, shapes how ideas and information in texts are understood. (I)
Use figurative language for intentional effects when expressing ideas or conveying information. (C)
**III. BIG IDEA: Techniques** Students explain, analyze, and use various techniques to comprehend and shape meaning.
**Narrative Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use narrative techniques to shape understandings.
Analyze the use of narrative techniques to present ideas, design texts, and convey information about characters, setting, and plot. (I)
Describe how the text’s protagonist and antagonist function in the plot, drive the conflict, and contribute to the development of other characters. (I)
Identify and describe common themes in texts (e.g., good vs. evil) that are revealed through details about characters. (I)

Compare and contrast the approach to similar themes and topics (e.g., opposition of good and evil) and patterns of events (e.g., the quest) in stories, myths, and traditional literature from diverse cultures. (I)

Apply narrative techniques (e.g., character, setting, problem, resolution, and dialogue) to develop a real or imagined experience using descriptive details, clear event sequences, and a conclusion. (C)
**Expository Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use expository techniques to shape understandings.
Discuss and evaluate techniques used to present and design expository texts, including facts and key details used to support the main idea. (I)
Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text. (I)
Integrate and classify information from multiple texts on the same topic in relationship to important points and key details. (I)
**Opinion Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use opinion techniques to shape understandings.
Discuss and evaluate techniques used to present and design opinion and argumentative texts, including author’s opinion or claim, supporting reasons, and evidence. (I)

Apply opinion techniques to create opinion pieces that introduce the topic, state an opinion about the topic, supply reasons and evidence to support the opinion with linking words (e.g., because, therefore, since, for example) to connect the opinion and reasons, and provide a concluding statement or section. (C)
**Poetic Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use poetic techniques to shape understandings.
Discuss and explain techniques used to present and design different types of poetry, including free verse, rhymed verse, haiku, and limerick. (I)
Apply poetic techniques to produce poetry and engage audiences that use a predetermined rhyme scheme to achieve an intended effect. (C)
**IV. BIG IDEA: Research & Analysis** Students use, discuss, analyze, and curate texts as they engage in various conversations, activities, and projects about a range of grade-level texts and topics.

**Research & Inquiry** Conduct research to ask and answer questions that clarify, deepen, and extend understanding of a topic of interest using credible sources and communicating relevant and accurate information.
Generate questions about a self-selected topic of interest to be researched, asking open-ended questions to deepen and extend understanding of the topic and related ideas and information. (I)
Conduct research by locating, gathering, curating, and integrating information from multiple credible sources, including print, digital, and personal communication, about a self-selected topic. (I)
Consider and integrate information from research, including relevant and accurate evidence from two or more credible sources. (C)
**Curating Sources & Evidence** Integrate evidence from print and digital sources, assessing credibility and relevance and avoiding plagiarism.
Refer to specific passages or quotations from a text to support an idea, answer, or opinion. (I)
Determine the credibility and relevance of a source text based on known information about the author and/or organization. (I)
**I. BIG IDEA: Context** Students describe the influences of purpose and audience on texts.
**Purpose & Audience** Use knowledge of purposes and audiences, as well as the language that develops those relationships, to make meaning of texts in multiple modes.
Determine audience and explain multiple purposes found across a text. (I)
Classify various texts by mode and describe how the mode is impacted by audiences and contributes to the overall purpose and effect. (I)
Create multimodal texts, using features of pre-selected modes for a specific purpose and audience. (C)
**Authors & Speakers** Make connections between authors of texts, speakers in texts, varying perspectives, and the circumstances in which texts are produced.
Describe how a narrator or speaker’s perspective influences the text. (I)
This progression begins in 6th grade.
Make inferences about the context in which the text is written (e.g., time period, individual, situational). (I)

**Organization** Demonstrate and apply understanding of organizational structures and elements to create cohesive and engaging texts.
Describe how text features (e.g., chapter titles, diagrams) and text structure (e.g., chapters, problem/solution) function in conjunction to represent ideas and information coherently in texts. (I)
Design texts using a variety of text structures and features, according to purpose and audience. (C)
Use conjunctions and transition words or phrases, such as *similarly* and *in contrast,* to show relationships between ideas and information. (C)
Craft related ideas into coherent paragraphs that follow a logical structure using transitions. (C)
**Craft** Use language to interpret meaning and craft engaging texts.
Describe the impact of the use of figurative language such as similes, metaphors, idioms, hyperboles, and personification in response to audience and purpose, in various modes and genres. (I)
Use figurative language for intentional effects when expressing ideas or conveying information. (C)
**III. BIG IDEA: Techniques** Students explain, analyze, and use various techniques to comprehend and shape meaning.
**Narrative Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use narrative techniques to shape understandings.
Analyze the use of narrative techniques to present ideas, design texts, and convey information about characters, setting, and plot. (I)
Analyze how setting, events, conflict, and characterization contribute to the plot. (I)
Explain how a theme is demonstrated through a character’s growth or conflict resolution. (I)
Compare and contrast stories in the same genre (e.g., mysteries, adventures) from diverse cultures on their approaches to similar themes and topics. (I)

Apply narrative techniques (e.g., character, setting, conflict, climax, resolution, and dialogue) to develop a real or imagined experience using descriptive details, clear event sequences, and a conclusion. (C)
**Expository Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use expository techniques to shape understandings.
Discuss and evaluate techniques used to present and design expository texts, including multiple main ideas, facts, and key details used to support the main idea. (I)
Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text. (I)
Compare and contrast first and secondhand accounts of the same event or topic using primary and/or secondary sources. (I)
**Opinion Techniques** Explain, analyze, and use opinion techniques to shape understandings.
Discuss and evaluate techniques used to present and design opinion and argumentative texts, including author’s opinion or claim, supporting reasons, and evidence. (I)

**IV. BIG IDEA: Research & Analysis** Students use, discuss, analyze, and curate texts as they engage in various conversations, activities, and projects about a range of grade-level texts and topics.

**Research & Inquiry** Conduct research to ask and answer questions that clarify, deepen, and extend understanding of a topic of interest using credible sources and communicating relevant and accurate information.

**Curating Sources & Evidence** Integrate evidence from print and digital sources, assessing credibility and relevance and avoiding plagiarism.
Refer to specific passages or quotations from a text to support an idea, answer, or opinion, recording the referenced information’s page number. (I)
Determine credibility and relevance by assessing the strengths and weaknesses of source texts to support a topic or message. (I)
Use basic parenthetical citations to credit the source used. (C)
**Syntax** Apply understanding of syntax to comprehend, analyze, condense, and combine ideas and information, enhancing clarity, style, and meaning.
Apply understandings of syntax to comprehend and analyze a variety of grade-level texts. (I)
Use a variety of simple, compound, and complex sentences, and compound- complex sentences to condense and combine ideas, maintaining consistent verb tense throughout the text. (C)
Identify and use active voice in sentences, revising for subject-verb agreement. (C)
Build and enrich ideas and information in texts, using modifiers when incorporating details and descriptions to convey meaning and facilitate engagement. (C)
**Syntax** Apply understanding of syntax to comprehend, analyze, condense, and combine ideas and information, enhancing clarity, style, and meaning.
Apply understandings of syntax to comprehend and analyze a variety of grade-level texts. (I)
Use a variety of simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex sentences to condense and combine ideas, maintaining consistent verb tense throughout the text. (C)
Distinguish between active and passive voice, revising texts to maintain consistency in active voice. (C)
Build and enrich ideas and information in texts, avoiding misplaced or dangling modifiers when incorporating details and descriptions to convey meaning and facilitate engagement. (C)
**Syntax** Apply understanding of syntax to comprehend, analyze, condense, and combine ideas and information, enhancing clarity, style, and meaning.
Apply understandings of syntax to comprehend and analyze a variety of grade-level texts. (I)
Use a variety of simple, compound, complex and compound-complex sentences, to condense and combine ideas, maintaining consistent verb tense throughout the text. (C)
Distinguish between active and passive voice, revising texts to maintain consistency in active voice. (C)
Build and enrich ideas and information in texts, integrating modifying phrases and clauses and eliminating misplaced or dangling modifiers to convey meaning and facilitate engagement. (C)
**I. BIG IDEA: Context** Students recognize influences on texts and analyze how they shape meaning.
**Purpose & Audience** Analyze the impact of purpose and audience on a wide variety of texts.
Analyze the development of multiple purposes within a single text and how those purposes target specific audiences. (I)
Use text mode features to aid comprehension and analysis of a variety of disciplinary texts and their related contexts. (I)
Construct multimodal texts and/or presentations for a specific purpose and audience. (C)
**Authors & Speakers** Analyze how authors’ and/or speakers’ perspectives influence texts and how circumstances shape their creation.
Describe and analyze the development and interaction of two or more perspectives conveyed by a single text. (I)
Explain how the author’s choice of evidence reveals the author’s perspective and impacts credibility. (I)
Identify and analyze the impact of background information and context (e.g., geography, location, era, historical happenings) on text development. (I)
Use credible sources to research the answers to questions on academic and individual topics of interest. (C)
**II. BIG IDEA: Structures & Style** Students analyze and use organizational structures and style to shape ideas and information.
**Organization** Analyze and use organizational structures to craft meaning.
Explain how authors modify text structures or features to convey meaning, respond to the audience, or achieve specific purposes. (I)
Design texts, flexibly employing a variety of text structures and text features to convey information and add style, as appropriate to purpose and audience. (C)
Use concept repetition and connected terms to support transitions, clarify the relationship between ideas and information in texts, and increase text cohesion. (C)
Craft multi-paragraph texts using a coherent structure to organize ideas with an introduction; supporting facts, reasons, details, descriptions, and/or events; and a conclusion. (C)
**Craft** Interpret and use language to craft engaging texts.
Determine how figurative and connotative language choices contribute to meaning, mood, or tone in a wide variety of texts. (I)
Use figurative language or literary devices for intentional effects when creating texts to achieve specific purposes or appeal to the target audience. (C)

Compare and contrast characteristics of formal style (e.g., jargon, complete sentences) with those of informal style (e.g., contractions, slang, sentence fragments) and apply understandings to writing and speaking. (C)
**III. BIG IDEA: Techniques** Students analyze and apply various techniques to comprehend and shape meaning.
**Narrative Techniques** Analyze and apply narrative techniques.
Describe how narrative techniques are used across the text to develop plot, characters, and setting. (I)
Analyze how setting, events, conflict, and characterization influence plot pacing. (I)
Identify multiple themes and describe how the relationships and interactions between characters influence and shape themes. (I)
Compare and contrast literary texts in different modes and genres (e.g., historical novels and fantasy texts) in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics. (I)
Apply narrative techniques to enhance writing, engage audiences, and achieve specific purposes. (C)
**Expository Techniques** Analyze and apply expository techniques.
Recognize and describe expository techniques used to present and design content, including main ideas, facts, key details, and a sense of closure. (I)
Compare and contrast one author’s presentation of events with that of another on the same historical event or topic. (I)
Apply expository techniques (e.g., main idea, facts, key details, sense of closure) to enhance writing and engage audiences. (C)
**Argumentative Techniques** Analyze and apply argumentative techniques.

Recognize and explain argumentative techniques used to present and design content, including an author’s claim, supporting relevant evidence, an identified counterclaim, and a conclusion that logically follows the argument. (I)
Apply argumentative techniques (e.g., author’s claim, supporting relevant evidence, an identified counterclaim, and a logical conclusion) to enhance writing and engage audiences. (C)
**Poetic Techniques** Analyze and apply poetic techniques.
Recognize and describe poetic techniques used to present and design content, including stanzas, rhyme scheme, imagery, figurative language, and/or sound devices. (I)
Apply poetic techniques (e.g., stanzas, rhyme/rhyme scheme, imagery, figurative language, sound devices) to produce poetry and engage audiences. (C)
**IV. BIG IDEA: Research & Analysis** Students use, discuss, analyze, and curate texts as they engage in various conversations, activities, and projects about a range of grade-level texts and topics.
**Research & Inquiry** Conduct research, generating questions to guide investigations of complex topics of interest and using credible resources to support analyses.
Generate questions to guide research and make connections between related topics of interest, formulating questions to investigate complex topics and ideas. (I)
Draw from accumulated knowledge and research to analyze texts, supporting, challenging, or extending ideas and information. (I)
Conduct research by locating, gathering, curating, and integrating information from reliable sources (including print, digital, and personal communication) about texts and related topics. (C)

**Curating Sources & Evidence** Utilize multiple print and digital texts to address a specific topic or question, assessing source credibility and relevance and integrating evidence properly to avoid plagiarism.
Locate evidence in print and digital sources to support a central idea or question, recording basic bibliographic information, such as author, title, and page number. (I)
Analyze print and digital texts to identify features of credible, relevant sources and to determine indicators that might signal unreliable sources. (I)
Use basic parenthetical citations to credit authors when quoting or paraphrasing texts, ensuring each source is accompanied by a basic entry on a works cited page. (C)

Read and comprehend one genre of literature from a particular time period. (I)

Use text mode features to aid comprehension and analysis of a variety of disciplinary texts and their related contexts. (I)
Construct multimodal texts and/or presentations for a specific purpose and audience, using multiple, clearly identifiable features of incorporated modes. (C)
**Authors & Speakers** Analyze how authors’ and/or speakers’ perspectives influence texts and how circumstances shape their creation.
Determine the prevailing perspectives in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes or corroborates that position. (I)
Analyze how evidence and tone reveal the author’s perspective and impact credibility. (I)
Analyze the impact of background information and context (e.g., geography, location, era, historical happenings) on text development. (I)
Use credible sources to research the answers to questions on academic and individual topics of interest. (C)

**Organization** Analyze and use organizational structures to craft meaning.
Analyze the impact of how authors modify text structures or features to convey meaning, respond to the audience, or achieve specific purposes. (I)
Design texts, flexibly employing a variety of text structures and text features to convey information and add style, as appropriate to purpose and audience. (C)
Use varied transition words and phrases to connect ideas, sentences, paragraphs, and sections of text. (C)
Craft multi-paragraph texts using a coherent structure with an introduction that guides the focus; supporting facts, reasons, details, descriptions, and/or events; and a conclusion. (C)
**Craft** Interpret and use language to craft engaging texts.
Explain how figurative language, connotative language, and literary device choices contribute to meaning, mood, or tone in a wide variety of texts. (I)
Use figurative language, literary devices, or connotative language for intentional effects when creating texts to achieve specific purposes or appeal to the target audience. (C)
Determine situational use for formal or informal style and apply that determination to choices when writing or speaking. (C)
**III. BIG IDEA: Techniques** Students analyze and apply various techniques to comprehend and shape meaning.
**Narrative Techniques** Analyze and apply narrative techniques.
Analyze how narrative techniques are used across the text to develop plot, characters, and setting. (I)
Analyze the use of plot structures, conflict, and narrative devices (e.g., flashback, foreshadowing) within a text. (I)
Compare and contrast how themes are developed and expressed in texts through characters, events, and other story elements. (I)
Compare and contrast a fictional portrayal of a time, place, or character with a historical account of the same period. (I)
Apply narrative techniques to enhance writing, engage audiences, and achieve specific purposes. (C)
**Expository Techniques** Analyze and apply expository techniques.

Apply argumentative techniques strategically to enhance writing and engage audiences. (C)
Integrate multiple rhetorical devices or appeals strategically. (C)
**Poetic Techniques** Evaluate and apply poetic techniques to enhance text’s appeal to audiences or achieve specific purposes.
Read, discuss, evaluate, and critique a variety of poetic texts, considering poetic techniques used to present and design content and their associated implications on meaning and/or theme. (I)
Apply knowledge of various poetic techniques and conventions to create poetic text for an intended purpose. (C)
**IV. BIG IDEA: Research & Analysis** Students use, discuss, analyze, and curate texts as they engage in various conversations, activities, and projects about a range of grade-level texts and topics.

**Research & Inquiry** Conduct research to ask and answer questions that clarify, deepen, and extend understanding of a topic of interest using credible sources and communicating relevant and accurate information.
Generate questions to guide research, make connections between complex topics, explore creative solutions, narrow focus, and/or refine text creation. (I)

Synthesize information from a variety of credible sources to support a central thesis, citing the sources of quoted, paraphrased, and summarized ideas following the guidelines of Modern Language Association (MLA) format or American Psychological Association (APA) format. (C)
Integrate paraphrased, summarized, and quoted material into original texts in various ways for intended purposes that strengthen the writing, citing appropriately. (C)
**Curating Sources & Evidence** Reference parts of texts to address a specific topic or question and explore various sources of information to make connections across a broad range of topics.
Navigate and use a variety of credible print and digital sources, including academic databases, to locate relevant information about a central argument, topic, or question. (I)

Analyze information from a variety of sources by identifying misconceptions; conflicting information or perspectives; and/or author bias and verifying the validity, relevancy, and accuracy of the information being considered. (I)

Follow Modern Language Association (MLA) guidelines when responding to inferential questions about texts or when integrating and citing textual evidence, ensuring each source is accompanied by a basic entry on a works cited page. (C)
**V. BIG IDEA: Periods & Movements** Students demonstrate knowledge of dominant themes, genres, and verbal styles of literature from a particular time period.
Demonstrate knowledge of dominant themes, genres, and verbal styles of literature from a particular time period.
Compare and contrast the works of writers and artists who are part of a specific movement during a particular time period. (I)
Compare and contrast major authors and works of three periods of English and American literary history, including key themes and stylistic features. (I)
**Syntax** Apply understanding of syntax to comprehend, analyze, evaluate, craft, and reshape sentences to achieve desired effects.
Apply understandings of syntax to comprehend, analyze, and evaluate a wide variety of texts, recognizing instances of parallel structure. (I)
Compose texts with varied syntax, reshaping sentences for effect while maintaining consistency of verb tenses, aspects, and moods. (C)
Maintain consistent use of active voice throughout a text to communicate clearly and concisely. (C)
Expand and enrich ideas and information, incorporating details and descriptions to achieve specific purposes or facilitate engagement. (C)
Recognize and use parallel structure within a sentence to create symmetry and convey a congruence of ideas. (C)
**Syntax** Apply understanding of syntax to comprehend, analyze, evaluate, craft, and reshape sentences to achieve desired effects.
Apply understandings of syntax to comprehend, analyze, and evaluate a wide variety of texts, including analyzing instances of parallel structure. (I)
Compose texts with varied syntax, reshaping sentences for effect while maintaining consistency of verb tenses, aspects, and moods. (C)
Maintain consistent use of active voice throughout a text for deliberate effect. (C)
Expand and enrich ideas and information, incorporating details and descriptions to achieve specific purposes or facilitate engagement. (C)
Recognize and use parallel structure within a paragraph to create symmetry and convey a congruence of ideas. (C)
**I. BIG IDEA: Grammar Conventions** Students observe, analyze, and use the structures and conventions of Standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics as they interpret and construct texts.
**Syntax** Apply understanding of syntax to comprehend, analyze, evaluate, craft, and reshape sentences to achieve desired effects.
Apply understandings of syntax to comprehend, analyze, and evaluate a wide variety of texts, including evaluating instances of parallel structure. (I)
Compose texts with varied syntax, reshaping sentences for style and effect while maintaining consistency of verb tenses, aspects, and moods. (C)
Maintain consistent use of active or passive voice throughout a text, as determined by the purpose, audience, and discipline. (C)
Expand and enrich ideas and information, incorporating details and descriptions to achieve specific purposes and facilitate engagement. (C)
Use and revise parallel structure across paragraphs or sections to create symmetry and convey a congruence of ideas. (C)

**II. BIG IDEA: Vocabulary** Students engage in a wide range of written and spoken activities during which they expand and deepen their vocabularies, build word analysis skillsets (morphology), and determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.

**General, Academic, & Specialized Vocabulary** Use a variety of approaches to continuously build vocabulary across a range of real-life, academic, and disciplinary contexts and apply those understandings to analyze texts and to communicate effectively.
Acquire a range of general, academic, and disciplinary vocabulary through grade-level print, digital, and/or multimodal texts or content. (I)
Use grade-level general, academic, and disciplinary vocabulary to communicate clearly and precisely in a variety of settings. (C)
**Word Analysis** Use word knowledge and word analysis skills to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words and phrases and to communicate effectively for a variety of purposes.
Deconstruct words using etymology knowledge, Greek and Latin roots, root words, and/or affixes to determine or clarify meaning in grade-level texts. (I)
Apply knowledge of parts of speech to determine the meanings of words and phrases in grade-level texts. (I)
Construct words based on knowledge of Greek and Latin roots, root words, and/or affixes and use those words appropriately in context. (C)
Use knowledge of parts of speech to determine precise words and phrases when constructing texts. (C)
**Meaning & Purpose** Analyze the denotative and connotative meanings of words and phrases and strategically apply those understandings when interpreting and constructing texts.

Analyze relationships between words, phrases, and/or clauses (e.g., synonyms, antonyms, analogies, contextual clues) to determine, distinguish, or clarify the meaning of unknown or multiple-meaning words and phrases. (I)
Distinguish between the connotations of words that share a similar denotation (e.g., confident, assertive, egotistic, pompous, smug). (I)

Use available print and/or digital resources, including reference materials and digital tools (e.g., online search, embedded word processing features), to determine, clarify, or verify the meaning of unknown or multiple-meaning words and phrases. (I)
Determine or clarify the nuanced meanings of closely related words or phrases using available print and/or digital resources to make strategic decisions when speaking and writing. (C)
